tn.text: The word "Ah" expresses Jonah's feeling of frustration.

tn.ref: is this not just what I said when I was back in my own country?
tn.text: Jonah used this rhetorical question to show God how angry he was. Also, what Jonah said when he was back in his own country can be stated explicitly. AT: "When I was still in my own country I knew that if I warned the people of Nineveh, they would repent, and you would not destroy them" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])

tn.ref: I acted first and tried to flee to Tarshish
tn.text: Possible meanings are 1) "I tried to prevent this by fleeing to Tarshish" or 2) "I acted quickly and tried to flee to Tarshish" or 3) "I did all I could to flee to Tarshish."
"very faithful" or "you love people very much" (UDB)
This means "you say that you will send disaster on sinners, but then you decide not to." AT: "you decide not to punish people who sin"
Jonah's reason for wanting to die can be stated explicitly. AT: "since you will not destroy Nineveh as you said you would, please allow me to die" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])

tn.ref: for it is better for me to die than to live
tn.text: "I would prefer to die than live" or "because I want to die. I do not want to live"

tn.ref: Is it good that you are so angry?
tn.text: God used this rhetorical question to scold Jonah for being angry about something he should not have been angry about. AT: "Your anger is not good." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
"left the city of Nineveh"

tn.ref: what might become of the city
tn.text: "what would happen to the city" (UDB). Jonah wanted to see if God would destroy the city or not destroy it.

tn.ref: over Jonah so that it might be a shade over his head
tn.text: "over Jonah's head for shade"
"to protect Jonah from the heat of the sun"
"God sent a worm" (UDB)
"The worm chewed the plant"
The plant became dry and died. AT: "the plant died"

tn.ref: God prepared a hot east wind
tn.text: God caused a hot wind from the east to blow on Jonah. If wind can only mean a cool or cold wind then you can try this. AT: "God sent a very hot warmth from the east to Jonah" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
"the sun was very hot"
Jonah may have felt the heat most on his head. AT: "on Jonah" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
"he became very weak" or "he lost his strength"

tn.ref: It is better for me to die than to live
tn.text: "I would prefer to die than live" or "Because I want to die. I do not want to live." See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:jon:04:01|4:3]].

tn.ref: Is it good that you are so angry about the plant?
tn.text: God challenges Jonah for being angry that the plant died and yet wanted God to kill the people of Nineveh. AT: "Your anger about the plant dying is not good." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])

tn.ref: Is it good that you are so angry about the plant?
tn.text: implicit information can be made explicit. AT: "You should be more concerned about the people in Nineveh dying than about the plant dying." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])

tn.ref: It is good that I am angry, even to death.
tn.text: "It is good that I am angry. Now I am angry enough to die!" (UDB)
"Yahweh said to Jonah" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])

tn.ref: should I not have compassion for Nineveh, that great city ... cattle?
tn.text: God used this question to emphasize his claim that he should have compassion on Nineveh. AT: "I certainly should have compassion for Nineveh, that important city ... cattle." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
This can also be the beginning of a new sentence. AT: "There are more" or "It has more"

tn.ref: one hundred and twenty thousand people
tn.text: 120,000 people (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_numbers]])

tn.ref: who do not know the difference between their right hand and their left hand
tn.text: This may be a way of saying "they cannot tell the difference between right and wrong."

The author is pointing out the depth of Nineveh's repentance to the extent that Yahweh takes note of the beasts' participation in the act of repentance. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:writing_background]])
